scenario:
McDonald's (MCD) has underperformed the S&P 500 in five of the past six years, with a track record of -2.2% in 2024, 12.5% in 2023, -1.7% in 2022, 24.9% in 2021, 8.6% in 2020, and 11.3% in 2019 compared to the S&P 500's 23.3%, 24.2%, -19.4%, 26.9%, 16.3%, and 28.9% respectively. The company's stock is currently trading at 26 times its trailing earnings, a rich multiple for a business facing challenges in growing its top and bottom lines.

McDonald's has been able to push higher costs to customers in the past, but this may not be as easy anymore, with global comparable sales down by 1.5% in the most recent quarter and a modest 0.3% increase in the core U.S. market. The company may need to be more competitive on price, which could boost sales but worsen margins and lower profits.

Despite its underperformance, McDonald's still offers value as a dividend growth stock and a stable investment, with a 2.4% dividend yield and a 47% rise in shares over the past five years, climbing to 65% including its dividend. However, investors should not expect this to be a market-beating growth stock or for 2025 to be a smooth year for the company.
